title: Welcome to DelibGraph
text:
You’re looking at a real discussion from an online deliberation platform. Instead of reading a long comment thread, this Knowledge Graph lets you see how ideas connect—so you can spot patterns, points of tension, and shared themes.

An AI analysed the discussion and created clusters and keywords. You stay in control: click nodes to read the original contributions and verify what you see.

title: Start from the Subject
text: The Subject is the main topic of the discussion. Think of it as your central anchor: everything in the debate connects back to it.

title: Compare Positions
text: Positions are the main viewpoints people take. Use them to quickly compare where participants stand and how the debate branches out.

title: Read the Arguments
text:
Arguments are human contributions written in relation to a specific position. The authors classified each contribution as either supporting the position (IN FAVOR) or challenging it (AGAINST).

Tip: Click any node to open its details and trace the argument back to the source.

title: Discover Thematic Clusters
text:
Clusters (the background areas) are suggested by AI. They group arguments that talk about similar themes—helping you see what the debate is really about.

Clusters are a starting point: explore inside them to confirm nuance and context.

title: Follow Shared Keywords
text:
Keywords are key terms extracted by AI. They act as semantic bridges by linking arguments that use the same concept—often connecting different sides of the discussion.

Use keywords to jump across the debate and compare how a concept is used.

title: Connections at a Glance
text: Node Size shows how connected something is: larger nodes have more links to other elements. This helps you spot central arguments, recurring themes, or highly referenced positions.

title: Now Explore
text:
You’re ready. Try these moves:
• Click nodes to read details and trace sources.
• Use the Timeline to replay how the debate evolves.
• Use Filters to find patterns like contested areas, shared keywords, or lone voices.
